title: 109_hr3637
content: The Act titled "Social Security Benefit Protection Act of 2005" aims to protect Social Security benefits from being reduced due to Part D Medicare premium increases. The "Social Security Benefit Protection Act of 2005" safeguards Social Security benefits from reduction caused by Part D Medicare premium hikes. The Act includes provisions to protect enrollees in prescription drug plans and ensures the preservation of monthly benefits under specific sections of the Social Security Act and the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. The Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 protects Social Security benefits from reduction due to Part D Medicare premium increases. It decreases the base beneficiary premium for individuals enrolled in PDP or MA-PD plans in November and December of the previous year. The adjusted national average monthly bid amount increase for a month in the year compared to the previous year does not apply to individuals with full premium subsidies under section 1860D-14(a)(1). For individuals with partial premium subsidies, there is a special rule in place. The annual increase in premium for individuals enrolled in part B is determined by section 1839(a)(3) and may be reduced under section 1839(f). The annual premium increase for part B enrollees is determined by section 1839(a)(3) and can be reduced under section 1839(f). Changes are made to the Medicare Advantage program and payment from the Medicare prescription drug account. Changes are made to the Medicare Advantage program and payment from the Medicare prescription drug account, including payment for social security benefit protection premium reductions. The Secretary will provide payment to PDP sponsors or MA organizations for part D eligible individuals enrolled in their plans with premium reductions under section 1860D-13(a)(1)(F), equivalent to the reduced premium amount. Payment methods and information disclosure rules from section 1860D-15 apply to these payments. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to premiums for months starting in January 2007, while the amendment made by subsection (b) will take effect upon the enactment of this Act.
